title: Throwing net
data:
***Version [0.31](/0.31 "0.31")**: This article **may not be** up to date for the [latest stable release](/0.32 "0.32") of Crawl.*

| Name                                           | Throwing net                     |
| :--------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| Launcher                                       | [Throwing](/Throwing "Throwing") |
| Base damage                                    | 0                                |
| [Base delay](/Weapon_speed "Weapon speed") (%) | 10 (100%)                        |
| [Min delay](/Minimum_delay "Minimum delay")    | 7 at skill 6                     |

|   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| - | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|   | A mesh of ropes knotted together with weights around the edge. Originally used by hunters to entangle and entrap prey, it soon found obvious application in battle and gladiatorial arenas. Struggling victims can eventually destroy the net and break free, if they live long enough.***"The look of a scared thing Sitting in a net!"-Edna St. Vincent Millay, "When the Year Grows Old". 1917. |

**Throwing nets** are [Throwing](/Throwing "Throwing") implements which deal no damage directly, but [ensnare](/Constriction "Constriction") their foe, lowering their [evasion](/Ev "Ev") and allowing [stabbing](/Stab "Stab") attacks.

## Contents

- [1 Useful Info](#Useful_Info)
  - [1.1 Mulching](#Mulching)
- [2 Sources](#Sources)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 History](#History)
- [5 References](#References)

## Useful Info

Nets can be used to ensnare opponents. If the net hits, it has the following effects:

- [EV](/EV "EV") of the target is reduced

  - Player EV is divided by 2
  - Monster EV is divided by `2 + body size` (tiny is 1, little is 2, etc.)

- Prevents physical movement (including abilities like [hopping](/Barachi "Barachi")), melee attacks, and use of [ranged weapons](/Ranged_weapon "Ranged weapon")

- Monsters are vulnerable to low-tier [stabs](/Stab "Stab")

[Insubstantial](/Insubstantial "Insubstantial") and [jelly](/List_of_jellies "List of jellies") creatures are immune to nets. Player with the [slick slippers](/Slick_slippers "Slick slippers") unrand are also immune.

Creatures can struggle through a net, which will eventually break it. Nets can also be escaped via [blink](/Blink "Blink"), [teleport](/Teleport "Teleport"), and certain abilities (like [Ru](/Ru "Ru")'s Draw Out Power and [Zin](/Zin "Zin")'s Sanctuary).

Unlike other [Throwing](/Throwing "Throwing") implements, monsters do not have infinite ammo with throwing nets.

### Mulching

Victims will struggle if they try to move or melee attack. Eventually, the net will break, letting them free.

Every time a victim struggles, they deal `1d4` "damage" to the net. After taking 8 or more damage, the net breaks.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) If they die or escape via other means (such as teleportation), the net has a `damage in 9` chance of being destroyed. [\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

The [Apportation](/Apportation "Apportation") spell can be used to recover a net, even if it's still on a monster. This can mulch the net, as if the monster had otherwise died/escaped. You cannot apport nets that are on you.

## Sources

[Gladiators](/Gladiator "Gladiator") begin play with a stack of throwing nets, and they can be found as random loot throughout the Dungeon. They are also held by [gnolls](/Gnoll_\(monster\) "Gnoll (monster)") and [merfolk](/List_of_merfolk "List of merfolk"), though they'll usually throw the net at you, first.

[Net traps](/Net_trap "Net trap"), mostly found in [Zot](/Zot "Zot"):5 and [the Tomb](/The_Tomb "The Tomb"), can drop a net on you, but these nets cannot be retrieved.

## Strategy

Nets can be used to escape from a monster, to stab enemies, or to get the edge during a dangerous fight. They are quite rare, so use them wisely. Keep in mind that nets are able to miss.

Few monsters in the game are immune to nets. Even "bosses" like [the Royal Jelly](/The_Royal_Jelly "The Royal Jelly"), all [pandemonium lords](/Pandemonium_lord "Pandemonium lord"), and 3 of the 4 [Hell](/Hell "Hell") lords ([Antaeus](/Antaeus "Antaeus") is giant) can be netted.

Watch out for enemy nets. As soon as you enter D:2, [gnolls](/Gnoll_\(monster\) "Gnoll (monster)") can generate with them. Nets are just as dangerous in enemy hands as yours; they can make a sticky situation that much more dangerous.

| Throwing net                                                                 |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [![Throwing net.png](/images/b/b4/Throwing_net.png)](/File:Throwing_net.png) |

## History

- Prior to [0.31](/0.31 "0.31"), [giant](/Size#Giant "Size") creatures were immune to nets, but jellies weren't.
- Prior to [0.26](/0.26 "0.26"), you could retrieve nets dropped from [net traps](/Net_trap "Net trap").
- Prior to [0.19](/0.19 "0.19"), the mechanics of escaping nets were more complicated. A creature caught in a net could escape it by either ripping the net or slipping out of it. Being [small](/Size#Small "Size"), [evasive](/EV "EV") and [dexterous](/Dexterity "Dexterity") (player only) made slipping out of nets more likely. On the other hand, [big](/Size#Big "Size"), [strong](/Strength "Strength"), and [berserking](/Berserk "Berserk") creatures were more likely to rip the net. Nearby creatures were adding tension, which sped up both escaping and destroying nets for the player. Cutting weapons, especially [flaming](/Flaming "Flaming") and [vorpal](/Vorpal "Vorpal") ones, as well as [claws](/Claws "Claws"), were good for shredding nets. Also, confused creatures, including the player, had a chance to struggle in a net without any result.
- Prior to [0.15](/0.15 "0.15"), any flying creature had an additional 66.6% chance to avoid any nets thrown at it, separate from the normal miss chance.
- Prior to [0.14](/0.14 "0.14"), flying opponents were completely immune to throwing nets, and instead of simply mulching, throwing nets would go through an elaborate deterioration process before finally falling apart entirely. Also, only medium or larger characters were able to use them.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [traps.cc:884](https://github.com/crawl/crawl/blob/0.30.0/crawl-ref/source/traps.cc#L884) (0.30.0)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [traps.h:17](https://github.com/crawl/crawl/blob/0.30.0/crawl-ref/source/traps.h#L17) (0.30.0)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [traps.cc:949](https://github.com/crawl/crawl/blob/0.30.0/crawl-ref/source/traps.cc#L949) (0.30.0)

| [Ranged Weapons](/Ranged_Weapons "Ranged Weapons")   | [Arbalest](/Arbalest "Arbalest") • [Hand cannon](/Hand_cannon "Hand cannon") • [Longbow](/Longbow "Longbow") • [Orcbow](/Orcbow "Orcbow") • [Shortbow](/Shortbow "Shortbow") • [Sling](/Sling "Sling") • [Triple crossbow](/Triple_crossbow "Triple crossbow")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| [Short Blades](/Short_Blades "Short Blades")         | [Dagger](/Dagger "Dagger") • [Quick blade](/Quick_blade "Quick blade") • [Rapier](/Rapier "Rapier") • [Short sword](/Short_sword "Short sword")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| [Staves](/Staves "Staves")                           | [Lajatang](/Lajatang "Lajatang") • [Magical staff](/Magical_staff "Magical staff") • [Quarterstaff](/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
| [Throwing](/Throwing "Throwing")                     | [Boomerang](/Boomerang "Boomerang") • [Dart](/Dart "Dart") • [Javelin](/Javelin "Javelin") • [Large rock](/Large_rock "Large rock") • [Stone](/Stone "Stone") • [Throwing net]()                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
html:
Throwing net

From CrawlWiki
Jump to: navigation, search
Version 0.31: This article may not be up to date for the latest stable release of Crawl.
Name Throwing net
Launcher Throwing
Base damage 0
Base delay (%) 10 (100%)
Min delay 7 at skill 6
A mesh of ropes knotted together with weights around the edge. Originally used by hunters to entangle and entrap prey, it soon found obvious application in battle and gladiatorial arenas. Struggling victims can eventually destroy the net and break free, if they live long enough.

"The look of a scared thing
Sitting in a net!"

-Edna St. Vincent Millay, "When the Year Grows Old". 1917.

Throwing nets are Throwing implements which deal no damage directly, but ensnare their foe, lowering their evasion and allowing stabbing attacks.

Contents

  • 1 Useful Info
    • 1.1 Mulching
  • 2 Sources
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 References

Useful Info

Nets can be used to ensnare opponents. If the net hits, it has the following effects:

  • EV of the target is reduced
    • Player EV is divided by 2
    • Monster EV is divided by 2 + body size (tiny is 1, little is 2, etc.)
  • Prevents physical movement (including abilities like hopping), melee attacks, and use of ranged weapons
  • Monsters are vulnerable to low-tier stabs

Insubstantial and jelly creatures are immune to nets. Player with the slick slippers unrand are also immune.

Creatures can struggle through a net, which will eventually break it. Nets can also be escaped via blink, teleport, and certain abilities (like Ru's Draw Out Power and Zin's Sanctuary).

Unlike other Throwing implements, monsters do not have infinite ammo with throwing nets.

Mulching

Victims will struggle if they try to move or melee attack. Eventually, the net will break, letting them free.

Every time a victim struggles, they deal 1d4 "damage" to the net. After taking 8 or more damage, the net breaks.[1][2] If they die or escape via other means (such as teleportation), the net has a damage in 9 chance of being destroyed. [3]

The Apportation spell can be used to recover a net, even if it's still on a monster. This can mulch the net, as if the monster had otherwise died/escaped. You cannot apport nets that are on you.

Sources

Gladiators begin play with a stack of throwing nets, and they can be found as random loot throughout the Dungeon. They are also held by gnolls and merfolk, though they'll usually throw the net at you, first.

Net traps, mostly found in Zot:5 and the Tomb, can drop a net on you, but these nets cannot be retrieved.

Strategy

Nets can be used to escape from a monster, to stab enemies, or to get the edge during a dangerous fight. They are quite rare, so use them wisely. Keep in mind that nets are able to miss.

Few monsters in the game are immune to nets. Even "bosses" like the Royal Jelly, all pandemonium lords, and 3 of the 4 Hell lords (Antaeus is giant) can be netted.

Watch out for enemy nets. As soon as you enter D:2, gnolls can generate with them. Nets are just as dangerous in enemy hands as yours; they can make a sticky situation that much more dangerous.

Throwing net

History

  • Prior to 0.31, giant creatures were immune to nets, but jellies weren't.
  • Prior to 0.26, you could retrieve nets dropped from net traps.
  • Prior to 0.19, the mechanics of escaping nets were more complicated. A creature caught in a net could escape it by either ripping the net or slipping out of it. Being small, evasive and dexterous (player only) made slipping out of nets more likely. On the other hand, big, strong, and berserking creatures were more likely to rip the net. Nearby creatures were adding tension, which sped up both escaping and destroying nets for the player. Cutting weapons, especially flaming and vorpal ones, as well as claws, were good for shredding nets. Also, confused creatures, including the player, had a chance to struggle in a net without any result.
  • Prior to 0.15, any flying creature had an additional 66.6% chance to avoid any nets thrown at it, separate from the normal miss chance.
  • Prior to 0.14, flying opponents were completely immune to throwing nets, and instead of simply mulching, throwing nets would go through an elaborate deterioration process before finally falling apart entirely. Also, only medium or larger characters were able to use them.

References

  1. ↑ traps.cc:884 (0.30.0)
  2. ↑ traps.h:17 (0.30.0)
  3. ↑ traps.cc:949 (0.30.0)

If the net hits, it has the following effects: *[[EV]] of the target is reduced **Player EV is divided by 2 **Monster EV is divided by 2 + [[size|body size]] (tiny is 1, little is 2, etc.) *Prevents physical movement (including abilities like [[Barachi|hopping]]), melee attacks, and use of [[ranged weapon]]s *Monsters are vulnerable to low-tier [[stab]]s [[Insubstantial]] and [[list of jellies|jelly]] creatures are immune to nets. Player with the [[slick slippers]] unrand are also immune. Creatures can struggle through a net, which will eventually break it. Nets can also be escaped via [[blink]], [[teleport]], and certain abilities (like [[Ru]]'s Draw Out Power and [[Zin]]'s Sanctuary). Unlike other [[Throwing]] implements, monsters do not have infinite ammo with throwing nets. ===Mulching=== Victims will struggle if they try to move or melee attack. Eventually, the net will break, letting them free. Every time a victim struggles, they deal 1d4 "damage" to the net. After taking 8 or more damage, the net breaks.{{source ref|0.30.0|traps.cc|884}}{{source ref|0.30.0|traps.h|17}} If they die or escape via other means (such as teleportation), the net has a damage in 9 chance of being destroyed. {{source ref|0.30.0|traps.cc|949}} The [[Apportation]] spell can be used to recover a net, even if it's still on a monster. This can mulch the net, as if the monster had otherwise died/escaped. You cannot apport nets that are on you. ==Sources== [[Gladiator]]s begin play with a stack of throwing nets, and they can be found as random loot throughout the Dungeon. They are also held by [[Gnoll (monster)|gnolls]] and [[list of merfolk|merfolk]], though they'll usually throw the net at you, first. [[Net trap]]s, mostly found in [[Zot]]:5 and [[the Tomb]], can drop a net on you, but these nets cannot be retrieved. ==Strategy== Nets can be used to escape from a monster, to stab enemies, or to get the edge during a dangerous fight. They are quite rare, so use them wisely. Keep in mind that nets are able to miss. Few monsters in the game are immune to nets. Even "bosses" like [[the Royal Jelly]], all [[pandemonium lord]]s, and 3 of the 4 [[Hell]] lords ([[Antaeus]] is giant) can be netted. Watch out for enemy nets. As soon as you enter D:2, [[Gnoll (monster)|gnolls]] can generate with them. Nets are just as dangerous in enemy hands as yours; they can make a sticky situation that much more dangerous. {| class="prettytable" style="border:none; margin:auto; padding:0; text-align: center" ! Throwing net |- | [[File:Throwing net.png]] |} ==History== *Prior to [[0.31]], [[Size#Giant|giant]] creatures were immune to nets, but jellies weren't. *Prior to [[0.26]], you could retrieve nets dropped from [[net trap]]s. *Prior to [[0.19]], the mechanics of escaping nets were more complicated. A creature caught in a net could escape it by either ripping the net or slipping out of it. Being [[Size#Small|small]], [[EV|evasive]] and [[dexterity|dexterous]] (player only) made slipping out of nets more likely. On the other hand, [[Size#Big|big]], [[Strength|strong]], and [[berserk]]ing creatures were more likely to rip the net. Nearby creatures were adding tension, which sped up both escaping and destroying nets for the player. Cutting weapons, especially [[flaming]] and [[vorpal]] ones, as well as [[claws]], were good for shredding nets. Also, confused creatures, including the player, had a chance to struggle in a net without any result. *Prior to [[0.15]], any flying creature had an additional 66.6% chance to avoid any nets thrown at it, separate from the normal miss chance. *Prior to [[0.14]], flying opponents were completely immune to throwing nets, and instead of simply mulching, throwing nets would go through an elaborate deterioration process before finally falling apart entirely. Also, only medium or larger characters were able to use them. ==References== {{weapons}} [[Category:Throwing]]
